column4: don't suppose you know of a way to force it to see wlan0? heh; the problem i'm having right now is that it doesn't see my wifi at all
I right clicked on the connection icon, clicked on Properties, and selected wlan0.  I connected once I did that.
yeah, that's what i'm saying, it doesn't see the device itself, under that, network tools, etc.; it doesn't detect it at all
it doesn't detect the NIC, haven't even gotten to trying to get it to see the network yet, heh
Have you gone to System > Preferences > Network Connections > Wireless and added you broadcast?
ssid, yes, left bssid and mac address blank, i'm not running any security, just have broadcast disabled and use mac filtering on the router
if i go to system -> administration -> network tools, it doesn't even list the device though, just eth0 and loopback
and i thought getting an ATI video card to work was frustrating, heh
That is one of the things I dislike about 9.10.  In 9.04, you had everything there. Now, you have to looking all over the place for it.  I am considering looking into using WICD.
i normally use Gentoo, but for whatever reason, it can't find the cd-rom after it gets to X point in the boot sequence
i was gonna try ubuntu because i heard it was good about seeing wireless NICs on laptops >_<
Mefached, IndyGunFreak: i'm feeling like a tool right now, i just stumbled across a toshiba-run site dedicated to linux support on their laptops lol
Mefached: well, it remains to be seen whether it's of any use, but it's at least something, heh; unfortunately, this laptop isn't on the (10 model) list of "certified products" :(
